instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hi, i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b which is not turning, but there is green light in charger.
i have measured following voltages:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 12.43v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>  is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ON_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is missing.
i have tried changing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> but it didn't fixed it, also the pch is getting hot when magsafe is connected to it.
board have no history of liquid damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Looks like bad PCH, if gets hot in off state...
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes sus voltages are present, i think its pch as its getting boiling hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
PCH has no reason to get hot in S5 state, when is powered only from <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and VCCRTC...
Sometime RTC block fails and sink to much current.
Your PCH is dead...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Can we replace pch from donor board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes but you have to clean the ME region. More of a time waster/rainy day project

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
For the price of a new PCH, I don't recommend to bother you reballing old one.
New PCH also requires clean ME region...
